column1:
FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH
 
 INDICATION:  Nasal intubation, cervical mass, evaluation for interval change.
 
 COMPARISON:  ___, 4:56 a.m.
 
 FINDINGS:  As compared to the previous radiograph, the patient has received an
 endotracheal tube.  The tip of the tube projects 6.5 cm above the carina.
 
 The pre-existing parenchymal opacities, predominating on the right, have
 slightly increased in extent, and now leads to blunting of the right
 costophrenic sinus.  This underlines the suspicion of pneumonia, as expressed
 in the previous report.
 
 No other changes.  Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette.  No evidence of
 pulmonary edema.

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Pain around the left sixth rib after fall 1 month prior. Evaluate
 for rib fracture.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral
 
 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph ___.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 The lungs are clear. There is no pleural effusion, pneumothorax or focal
 airspace consolidation. The heart is normal size. The mediastinal and hilar
 contours are unremarkable. There is no rib fracture seen.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 No acute cardiopulmonary process.

FINAL REPORT
 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST
 
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Patient with abdominal mass and tenderness.  Evaluate for
 free air.
 
 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW:  There is mild cardiomegaly.  The lungs are clear.  Aside
 from minimal atelectasis in the right base, there is no pneumothorax or
 pleural effusion.  There is no evidence of free air within the abdomen.

FINAL REPORT
 AP CHEST, 9:57 PM  ON ___
 
 HISTORY:  ___-year-old man with recent biliary system surgery, now with nausea,
 vomiting, and abdominal pain.
 
 IMPRESSION:  AP chest reviewed in the absence of prior chest radiographs:
 
 Examination is marked semi-upright.  No free air is seen below the plane of
 the diaphragm.  Small bilateral pleural effusions are present, as well as
 bibasilar atelectasis, left greater than right.  Heart size top normal.  No
 pneumothorax.  Upper lungs clear.

FINAL REPORT
 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST
 
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Patient with abdominal mass and tenderness.  Evaluate for

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with respiratory failure  // eval for interval
 change      eval for interval change
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 In comparison with the study of ___, the left IJ catheter has been
 removed.  The endotracheal tube and enteric tube are stable.
 Continued opacification at the left base with obscuration of the
 hemidiaphragm.  This suggests layering pleural fluid with some volume loss in
 the left lower lobe.  The opacification at the right base is decreasing and
 the hemidiaphragm is sharply seen on this side.  No evidence of vascular
 congestion or acute focal pneumonia.

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH PERFORMED ON ___
 
 COMPARISON:  Prior exam from ___.
 
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  Asthma, CAD, wheezing, question pneumonia or edema.
 
 FINDINGS:  Portable AP upright chest radiograph provided.  Lung volumes are
 low.  The heart is top normal in size.  There is no evidence of pneumonia or
 overt CHF.  No effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  The mediastinal contour is
 stable.  Bony structures are intact.
 
 IMPRESSION:  No acute findings.

FINAL REPORT
 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST
 
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Patient with abdominal mass and tenderness.  Evaluate for

 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW:  There is mild cardiomegaly.  The lungs are clear.  Aside

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE CHEST ___, ___ 
 
 COMPARISON:  ___ radiograph.
 
 FINDINGS:  Interval placement of a right pleural catheter with associated
 decrease in size of right pleural effusion, and no visible apical
 pneumothorax.  A horizontal interface in the lower right hemithorax just
 medial to the site of the pleural catheter could reflect a loculated basilar
 hydropneumothorax.  Cardiomediastinal contours are stable allowing for
 differences in lung volumes.  Bilateral pulmonary lung nodules are again
 visualized, in keeping with metastatic disease.  Destructive right rib lesions
 are seen to better detail on recent CT.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)
 
 INDICATION:  History: ___F with shortness of breath
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral
 
 COMPARISON:  ___
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Heart size is mildly enlarged. The mediastinal and hilar contours are
 unchanged.  Patchy opacities are noted in the lung bases, and not
 substantially changed from the previous exam. The pulmonary vasculature is
 normal.  No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is present. There are no acute
 osseous abnormalities.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Patchy bibasilar airspace opacities likely atelectasis.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with SOB and diminished breath sounds in L
 base, exp wheezing  // r/o PNA.  History of RULobectomy for recurrence lung CA
 ___      r/o PNA.  History of RULobectomy for recurrence lung CA ___
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 IN COMPARISON WITH THE STUDY OF ___, THE APICAL PNEUMOTHORAX ON THE
 RIGHT HAS CLEARED.  THERE IS DECREASED OPACIFICATION AT THE RIGHT BASE, THOUGH
 THERE IS STILL SUBSTANTIAL TENTING OF THE HEMIDIAPHRAGM WITH A DENSE STREAK OF
 OPACIFICATION HEADING UPPER TO THE RIGHT HILUM.  OTHERWISE, LITTLE CHANGE AND
 NO EVIDENCE OF APPRECIABLE VASCULAR CONGESTION.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___-year-old man with subarachnoid hemorrhage, hypoxia.  Evaluate
 for pulmonary edema
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Single portable semi upright chest radiograph
 
 COMPARISON:  None.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Low lung volumes.
 Heart size is at the upper limits of normal.  The mediastinal and hilar
 contours are normal. The pulmonary vasculature is normal. Lungs are clear.  No
 pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen. There are no acute osseous
 abnormalities.  Cervical spinal hardware is incompletely imaged.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  DX CHEST PORT LINE/TUBE PLCMT 3 EXAMS
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with recent aspiration event.  Post-op from left
 diaphragmatic hernia repair. Intubated for bronchoscopy, now extubated.  //
 Check Dobhoff tube placement, evaluate for infiltrates s/p aspiration (pill
 fragments seen in lungs on bronchoscopy).    Check Dobhoff tube placement,
 evaluate for infiltrates s/p aspiration (pill fragments seen in lungs on
 bronchoscopy).
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 In comparison with these earlier study of this date, the nasogastric tube is
 been removed and replaced with a Dobhoff tube that extends to the upper
 portion of the stomach, with the opaque portion of the tube at or just distal
 to the esophagogastric junction.
 The ETT appears tube been removed.  There is a breathing apparatus in place
 that makes it difficult to assess wet could be a tracheostomy tube.
 Bibasilar opacification is consistent with layering effusions and underlying
 compressive atelectasis.  Indistinctness of engorged pulmonary vessels is
 consistent with some elevation in pulmonary venous pressure in this patient
 with enlargement of the cardiac silhouette.

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE CHEST, ___
 
 COMPARISON:  ___ radiograph.
 
 FINDINGS:  Right atrial and right ventricular pacing/ICD leads are unchanged
 in position.  Tip of endotracheal tube is in standard position terminating 4.1
 cm above the carina, and a nasogastric tube terminates within the stomach. 
 Cardiomediastinal contours are stable allowing for patient rotation.  Apparent
 worsening opacity in the left cardiophrenic angle.  It is difficult to assess
 in the setting of rotation, but most likely represents a combination of
 pleural effusion and adjacent atelectasis.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)
 
 INDICATION:  ___M with motorcycle crash ___ with residual bony injury, which
 is unclear, presenting with acute severe left shoulder pain today after
 getting up from a chair.  Tenderness to palpation right shoulder and sternum.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral
 
 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph ___, CT chest ___
 from outside hospital, chest radiograph from outside hospital ___
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Heart size is normal.  The mediastinal and hilar contours are normal. The
 pulmonary vasculature is normal. Lungs are clear.  No pleural effusion or
 pneumothorax is seen.  Elevation of the right hemidiaphragm is unchanged. 
 Mild degenerative changes are noted involving the thoracic spine.  Multiple
 chronic left-sided rib fractures are again demonstrated with fixation hardware
 seen involving the left fifth through eighth ribs.  Comminuted fracture of the
 left midclavicle is chronic.
 
 IMPRESSION:
 
 
 1. No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.
 2. Multiple chronic left-sided rib fractures and comminuted left midclavicular
 fracture.

FINAL REPORT

 FINDINGS:  Interval placement of a right pleural catheter with associated

 medial to the site of the pleural catheter could reflect a loculated basilar

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with myasthenia ___ and admitted with
 worsening respiratory function secondary to his MG vs possible PNA  // pls
 eval interval change     pls eval interval change
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Comparison to ___.  The pre-existing left basal parenchymal opacity
 has decreased in extent and severity but remains clearly visible.  Resolving
 pneumonia or aspiration are the most likely differential diagnoses.  Normal
 size of the heart.  No pleural effusions.  No pulmonary edema.

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE CHEST FILM ___ AT 14:07
 
 CLINICAL INDICATION:  ___-year-old status post fall and hemorrhagic contusion,
 evaluate NG tube placement.
 
 Comparison made to ___.
 
 A portable semi-supine chest film ___ a 14:07 is submitted.
 
 IMPRESSION:
 
 1.  Nasogastric tube is seen coursing below the diaphragm with the tip coiled
 within the stomach.  Lungs are well inflated without evidence of focal
 airspace consolidation, pleural effusions or pulmonary edema.  Stable
 irregularity of the left posterolateral fourth rib which may be related to old
 trauma.  No acute bony abnormality.

FINAL REPORT

FINAL REPORT

 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with presumed hypersensitivity pneumonitis  //

 As compared to the previous radiograph, the bilateral parenchymal opacities

FINAL REPORT
 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST
 
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Rhonchi on the left upper lobe.  
 
 Cardiac size is top normal. Faint ill-defined opacities in the left upper lobe
 are consistent with pneumonia.  There are minimal atelectases in the right
 lower lobe.  There is no pleural effusion.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with port placed.  // Evaluate placement of
 port      Evaluate placement of port
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 In comparison with the study of ___, there again are low lung volumes
 accentuating the transverse diameter of the heart. Elevation of the right

 No evidence of vascular congestion or acute focal pneumonia.  No definite

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with new L parietal lesion  // Pre-op planning
 Surg: ___ (brain biopsy)     Pre-op planning
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 No comparison.  The lung volumes are normal.  Normal size of the cardiac

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  History: ___F with altered mental status
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Portable supine AP view of the chest
 
 COMPARISON:  ___
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Assessment is limited by patient positioning and rotation. Left-sided
 pacemaker device is noted with leads terminating in similar positions.
 Moderate cardiomegaly and tortuosity of the thoracic aorta are re-
 demonstrated with diffuse atherosclerotic calcifications noted within the
 aorta. Hilar contours are difficult to assess given the degree of patient
 rotation. Patchy opacity in the left lung base could reflect an area of
 atelectasis. Additional focal opacity is seen within the right mid lung field.
 No overt pulmonary edema is demonstrated. No large pleural effusion or
 pneumothorax is clearly visualized on this supine exam. Osseous structures are
 diffusely demineralized with loss of height of several mid thoracic vertebral
 bodies.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Limited exam.  Patchy opacities within the left lung base and right mid lung
 field are nonspecific, and may reflect areas of atelectasis though infection
 is not excluded. No overt pulmonary edema.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)
 
 INDICATION:  History: ___M with chest discomfort  // PNA?
 
 COMPARISON:  None available
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 There is no focal consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax. The
 cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal. Imaged osseous structures are intact. 
 No free air below the right hemidiaphragm is seen.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 No acute intrathoracic process.

FINAL REPORT
 STUDY:  AP Chest, ___.
 
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  ___-year-old man with tracheostomy and urosepsis.  Evaluate
 for interval changes.
 
 FINDINGS:  Comparison is made to previous study from ___ at 4:48
 a.m.
 
 There are unchanged air space opacities which are more confluent within the
 right upper lobe.  Atelectasis at the left lung base.  There is prominence of
 pulmonary interstitial markings.  Heart size is within normal limits.  There
 is shifting of the mediastinal structures to the right apex and suggestive of
 right upper lobe collapse.  There is a tracheostomy, which is appropriately
 sited.  Hardware in the lower cervical spine is also seen.  Overall, these
 findings appear stable.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  History: ___F with trach/vent, inc secretions, hypoxia.  KUB for
 LLQ pain  // Eval for PNA, evidence of high stool burden
 
 COMPARISON:  ___
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Left lower lobe opacity may represent pneumonia.  Right basal atelectasis is
 mild. Bilateral effusions are unchanged. There is no pneumothorax. The
 cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal. Imaged osseous structures are intact. 
 No free air below the right hemidiaphragm is seen.  Tracheostomy, left IJ
 venous line, and right subclavian Port-A-Cath are not significantly changed in
 position.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Left lower lobe opacity may represent pneumonia.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with NSTEMI s/p cath  // eval interval change    
 eval interval change
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Heart size and mediastinum are stable.  There is mild vascular congestion. 
 There is no appreciable pleural effusion.  There is no pneumothorax. 
 Pacemaker leads terminate in right atrium and right ventricle.

FINAL REPORT
 AP CHEST, 12:21 P.M. ON ___.
 
 HISTORY:  ___-year-old woman after right upper lobectomy.
 
 IMPRESSION:  AP chest compared to preoperative chest radiograph, ___:
 
 Right apical pleural tube in place.  Postoperative right lung well expanded,
 with no apparent persistent pleural space.  Opacification medial to the right
 upper lung abutting the mediastinum is probably hematoma, particularly given
 leftward displacement of the trachea.  Small left pleural effusion is new,
 probably not clinically significant.  Heart size is normal.

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH PERFORMED ON ___
 
 COMPARISON:  A prior study from same day.
 
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  Post-intubation, confirm position of the ET tube.
 
 FINDINGS:  Supine portable AP view of the chest is obtained.  The evaluation
 is limited as the lateral aspect of the right hemithorax is excluded.  The
 endotracheal tube is seen with its tip residing approximately 3.6 cm above the
 carina.  There has also been placement of a nasogastric tube with its tip in
 the right upper quadrant.  Otherwise, there has been no change with small
 bibasilar atelectasis and relative mediastinal prominence, which likely
 reflect portable AP technique.

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE CHEST ___, ___
 
 COMPARISON:  Study ___.
 
 FINDINGS:  The cardiomediastinal contours are stable in appearance.  Mild
 pulmonary vascular congestion is present.  Bilateral pleural effusions have
 increased in size in the interval, now moderate on the right and
 small-to-moderate on the left, with adjacent areas of bibasilar atelectasis
 and/or consolidation.

FINAL REPORT

 EXAMINATION:  Chest radiograph
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with hypoxemia in setting of subarachnoid
 hemorrhage, tachypnea.  // eval for volume loss, consolidation, edema.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Portable AP chest radiograph
 
 COMPARISON:  None.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Bilateral opacities are seen in the lung bases, which can be concerning for
 aspiration or infection.  Asymmetric edema is thought to be less likely but
 cannot be excluded. Moderate bibasilar atelectasis is noted. The heart size is
 normal.  No pneumothorax or pulmonary edema.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Bilateral opacities in the lung bases are concerning for aspiration,
 infection, or, less likely, asymmetric edema.
 
 NOTIFICATION:   The findings were discussed by Dr. ___ with NP ___  on
 the telephoneon ___ at 3:01 PM, 20 minutes after discovery of the
 findings.

FINAL REPORT

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST ON ___
 
 HISTORY:  Hypoxia, question pneumothorax.
 
 FINDINGS:  The Swan-Ganz catheter has been removed.  There is a right IJ
 Cordis with tip in the SVC.  There is bilateral lower lobe volume
 loss/infiltrate that is increased compared to the study from the prior day. 
 The upper lungs are clear.

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE CHEST X-___ OF ___
 
 COMPARISON:  Radiograph of one day earlier.
 
 Radiograph centered at thoracoabdominal junction was obtained for assessment
 of a nasogastric tube, which is now positioned proximally within the stomach. 
 Side port is likely just above the GE junction level.  The imaged portions of
 the lungs are clear.  Within the imaged abdomen, contrast is present within
 both renal collecting systems.  Correlation with timing of recent contrast
 injection is suggested as well as correlation with renal function.

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH
 
 INDICATION:  Right hemothorax, status post chest tube removal.
 
 COMPARISON:  ___, 11:52 a.m.
 
 FINDINGS:  As compared to the previous radiograph, the right-sided chest tube
 has been removed.  The pre-existing mild fluid or pneumothorax is unchanged in
 extent.  There currently are no signs of tension.  Minimal right basal fluid
 collection that is likely pleural.
 
 Low lung volumes, moderate cardiomegaly without pulmonary edema.  Mild gas
 collection in the right lateral soft tissues.

FINAL REPORT
 STUDY:  AP chest ___.
 
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  ___-year-old man with stroke.  Assess nasogastric tube.
 
 FINDINGS:  Comparison is made to previous study from ___.  
 
 There is a nasogastric tube whose tip is in the fundus of the stomach.  There
 is air seen throughout the stomach.  There is a dual-lead left-sided
 pacemaker.  Median sternotomy wires are seen.  Heart size is within normal
 limits.  Lungs are grossly clear.  There are no pneumothoraces identified.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with COPD exacerbation now with sudden SOB  //
 Please assess for acute cardiopulmonary process
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 As compared to ___, note is made of subtle new heterogeneous
 opacities in the right lower lung with associated bronchial wall thickening,
 concerning for developing infection in the appropriate clinical setting.  No
 other relevant changes.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  Chest radiograph
 
 INDICATION:  ___-year-old woman with question of pneumoperitoneum.  Evaluate
 for free air.
 
 TECHNIQUE:  Portable upright frontal radiograph view of the chest.
 
 COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph dated ___.
 Limited reference is made to the CT abdomen and pelvis from an outside
 facility dated ___ and uploaded onto PACS.
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 Midline sternotomy wires again noted with partially imaged hardware stable as
 Ing the lumbar spine.  Again noted is complete opacification of the left
 hemithorax and leftward shift of the mediastinum in this patient status post
 prior left pneumonectomy.  Hiatal hernia is better appreciated on the prior
 CT.  The right lung is clear.  No pneumothorax.  The heart and mediastinum
 cannot be assessed.  Residual barium noted within upper abdominal bowel loops.
 No evidence of subdiaphragmatic free air.  Dextroconvex scoliosis of the upper
 thoracic spine is more pronounced.  Clips projecting over the left hemithorax
 are unchanged.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 1.  No subdiaphragmatic free air.
 2.  Right lung is clear.  Post left pneumonectomy changes.

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH PERFORMED ON ___.
 
 COMPARISON:  None.
 
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  Cough, fever, question pneumonia.
 
 FINDINGS:  Portable AP upright chest radiograph obtained.  There is airspace
 consolidation within the left lower lobe, involving the left lower lobe
 superior segment and basal posterior segments.  Right lung is clear.  No large
 effusion is seen.  No pneumothorax.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal. 
 Bony structures are intact.
 
 IMPRESSION: Findings compatible with pneumonia in the left lower lobe,
 involving superior and basal segments.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___F with cough, fever  // PNA?
 
 COMPARISON:  None
 
 FINDINGS: 
 
 AP portable upright view of the chest.   Mild cardiomegaly is noted. Coarsened
 lung markings may reflect interstitial lung disease. No large effusion or
 pneumothorax is seen. No convincing signs of pneumonia. Patient rotation
 limits assessment. Allowing for this, the mediastinal contour is likely within
 normal limits. The bony structures are demineralized though appear intact.
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Mild cardiomegaly, probable chronic lung disease. No overt signs of pneumonia
 or edema.

FINAL REPORT

 hepatic encephalopathy and new fever.  // evaluate for PNA
 
 TECHNIQUE:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

 Cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged.  Slight worsening of bibasal
 consolidations demonstrated, concerning for development of pneumonia.  TIPS
 catheter is in place.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with recurrent aspiration PNA, on tube feeds,
 now with recurrent fever/tachycardia.  // eval for PNA/aspiration
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 As compared to ___ chest radiograph, cardiomediastinal contours are
 stable.  An nonspecific opacity in the right lower lobe has substantially

FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  ___-year-old woman status post right lung fiducial placement and
 biopsy.
 
 COMPARISON:  Radiograph earlier at 3:00 p.m. today.

FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with  Brainstem infarct intubated  // Please
 assess for interval change      Please assess for interval change
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 In comparison with the study of ___, the monitoring and support
 devices show little change.  The right IJ catheter extends to the cavoatrial

 with the tip pointing upward several cm below the level of the esophagogastric

 There is some increasing atelectatic changes at the left base with continued

FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE SEMI-UPRIGHT CHEST,  ___ AT 10:25 A.M.
 
 COMPARISON:  ___ at 8 a.m.
 
 FINDINGS:  Transvenous pacing lead continues to terminate in the right
 ventricle.  Other indwelling support and monitoring devices are unchanged in
 position.  Overall appearance of the chest is not appreciably changed since
 the recent study of less than three hours earlier, allowing for differences in
 positioning of the patient.

FINAL REPORT
 CHEST RADIOGRAPH PERFORMED ON ___
 
 COMPARISON:  None.
 
 CLINICAL HISTORY:  Weakness, question pneumonia.
 
 FINDINGS:  Portable AP upright chest radiograph was provided.  Lung volumes
 are markedly low and patient is rotated, which limits evaluation
 significantly.  No convincing signs of pneumonia on this markedly limited
 exam.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is impossible to assess.  No large
 pneumothorax or effusion.  Deformity of the right humeral head appears
 chronic.
 
 IMPRESSION:  Markedly limited exam without convincing signs of pneumonia. 
 Would recommend repeat exam if there is further clinical concern.

FINAL REPORT

 INDICATION:  ___ year old man with history of ETOH/HBV cirrhosis s/p TIPS with
 hepatic encephalopathy and new fever.  // evaluate for PNA
 
 TECHNIQUE:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
 
 COMPARISON:  ___
 
 IMPRESSION: 
 
 Right internal jugular line tip is at the cavoatrial junction. 
 Cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged.  Slight worsening of bibasal
 consolidations demonstrated, concerning for development of pneumonia.  TIPS
 catheter is in place.

FINAL REPORT
 REASON FOR EXAMINATION:  Evaluation of the patient with metastatic
 cholangiocarcinoma and multiple PEs, found to have malignant effusion,
 reassessment of effusion.
 
 AP radiograph of the chest was reviewed in comparison to ___.
 
 Heart size and mediastinum are grossly stable.  Bibasal consolidations are
 unchanged.  Small amount of bilateral pleural effusion is noted.  The right
 PICC line tip terminates at the level of low SVC.  Overall, since the prior
 study, there is increase in the basilar opacities and pleural effusions.

FINAL REPORT
 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE CHEST
 
 REASON FOR EXAM:  Patient with abdominal mass and tenderness.  Evaluate for
 free air.
 
 SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW:  There is mild cardiomegaly.  The lungs are clear.  Aside
 from minimal atelectasis in the right base, there is no pneumothorax or
 pleural effusion.  There is no evidence of free air within the abdomen.

 pneumomediastinum.  Calcific density overlying the body of the left scapula
 consistent with known sub scapularis calcific tendinitis.

 study.

 malignancy.
